executive_summary: The Flag Manufacturing industry includes operators that manufacture flags from purchased materials, including nylon, polyester and cotton. Similar to most textile manufacturing industries in the United States, the industry experiences intense competition from lower-priced imports. Goods manufactured domestically tend to command higher prices, largely due to the relatively high labor costs domestic producers pay compared with their international counterparts. Consequently, demand for industry products has declined as consumers have increasingly elected to purchase inexpensive, foreign-produced flags over the past five years.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Revenue has been decreasing at a CAGR of 3.1% over the past five years
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Revenue for the Flag Manufacturing industry has been decreasing at a CAGR of 3.1% over the past five years, and is expected to reach $83.8 million in 2023. This includes an expected increase of 0.4% in 2023 alone, when profit is projected to reach 5.0%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Coronavirus Pandemic Had a Negative Effect on Industry Revenue
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The onset of the coronavirus pandemic in 2020 hampered industry performance overall. Flag manufacturers were forced to temporarily close their establishments in line with the government-mandated closure of nonessential businesses.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Import Penetration Has Pressured the Industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The value of imports increased over the past five years, challenging flag manufacturers in the US. The trade-weighted index (TWI), which measures the value of the US dollar compared with its major trading partners, increased over the past five years, contributing to the rise of imports during the current period.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Operators Have Adapted to Remain Relevant
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: In response to the challenging operating conditions over the past five years, flag manufacturers in the US have had to adopt new strategies to stay competitive. Manufacturers have expanded their online presence to broaden their potential customer base and reach a global audience.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Revenue is expected to increase at a CAGR of 1.4% over the next five years
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Revenue for the Flag Manufacturing industry is expected to increase at a CAGR of 1.4% to $89.7 million over the five years to 2028, when profit is expected to reach 5.1%.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Competition from Imports Will Likely Ease
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the next five years, the trade-weighted index (TWI), which measures the value of the US dollar compared with its major trading partners, is forecast to decrease. This will contribute to a decline in the value of industry imports, slightly easing external competition for domestic operators.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Technological Advancements Are Expected to Be Key
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Technology and innovation will play a major role in the industry, including advancements in printing techniques and materials. The ability to provide customized options, particularly through digital design, will give manufacturers a competitive advantage.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Established Players Will Likely Continue to Dominate the Industry
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The Flag Manufacturing industry will continue to be dominated by established companies because of their strong customer recognition and historical significance that appeals to many buyers.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry manufacture flags from purchased materials, including nylon, polyester and cotton materials. Flags tend to be attached by one side to a pole and usually carry representative symbols or colors. The industry does not include the manufacture of banners or pennants.
key_trends: The onset of the coronavirus pandemic in 2020 hampered industry performance
The value of imports has increased over the past five years, challenging flag manufacturers
Flag manufacturers in the US have had to adopt new strategies to stay competitive
Flag manufacturers will continue capitalizing on e-commerce platforms to reach a wider audience and boost sales
Technology and innovation will play a major role in the industry
The Flag Manufacturing industry will continue to be dominated by established companies
During the period, rising e-commerce sales have hampered industry performance

market_segmentation.segment_description: This market segment includes wholesalers for resale. Wholesalers act as an intermediary between manufacturers and retailers. However, retailers increasingly have been purchasing goods directly from manufacturers to decrease costs. This wholesale bypass has led the wholesaler's segment to decrease as a share of revenue over the past five years.

This segment includes sales directly to retailers for resale and is the second-largest market for the industry. Retailers purchase industry goods to sell directly to the final consumer. The retail segment can be further broken down by type of retailer, like discount stores, department stores and online retailers. The retail segment has increased as a share of revenue over the past five years, primarily due to the decline in the use of wholesalers, permitting retailers to decrease costs.

This segment includes businesses for end use and government bodies. Businesses purchase flags directly from industry operators and do not resell or pass the product along any further down the supply chain. Similar to the retail segment, the contraction of the wholesale segment is expected to have increased this segment's share of revenue during the period.

Although demand from the government segment is expected to be consistent, it does not comprise a large share of revenue since government entities are not expected to increase their demand often and likely purchase long lasting products that do not need to be replaced frequently.

products_and_services.product_description: This segment includes American flags. Common materials used in the manufacturing of American flags include polycotton, premium nylon, durable polyester and colonial Nyl-Glo.

This segment includes military flags which encompasses flags for the US Space Force, Air Force, Army, Marine Corps, Navy and Coast Guard. Additionally, any memorial and remembrance flags related to the military are included in this segment.
This segment includes international and historical flags.
This segment includes the state flags for each US state.
This product segment includes all other flags not accounted for in the other product categories. Examples of other products within this segment include religious, sports, nautical and custom flags.

tier_1_suppliers: Synthetic Fiber Manufacturing in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Demand for the Flag Manufacturing industry is largely influenced by the level of patriotism in the United States. Strong patriotism generally increases demand for American flags, which account for a large portion of industry revenue.
American flag sales are expected to increase. A major player, Eder Flag Manufacturing Co. Inc., reported a 15.0% increase in sales in 2016 compared to 2015.

The demand for industry products is affected by seasonality. In general, industry operators experience higher demand during the summer months due to many patriotic holidays occurring during this season, such as Memorial Day, Independence Day, and Labor Day.

Other factors affecting demand for the industry include: 1) Per Capita Disposable Income - An increase translates to consumers being more able to purchase domestically manufactured flags. 2) Value of Private Residential and Private Nonresidential Construction - New buildings are more likely to purchase new flags.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Imported Flags Appeal to Budget-Conscious Buyers
international_trade_points.trade_description: Flags that are imported from countries with lower production costs, like lower minimum wages, can be more competitively priced, making them attractive to US consumers.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Trade Policies and Tariffs Affect Flag Imports
international_trade_points.trade_description: US trade policies and import tariffs can directly affect the cost and the volume of imported flags. For example, high tariffs make imports pricier and less appealing to domestic consumers.

Geopolitical relations between the US and other countries can significantly affect the export of flags. Positive relations may lead to increased exports, while negative relationships can pressure exports.

Exchange rate fluctuations directly affect the price competitiveness of American-made flags abroad. For example, a stronger US dollar typically decreases demand for the industry as US goods are more costly.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast is home to the largest number of establishments. The Southeast is also the most populated region in the United States, making it a strategic location for manufacturers as they are close to large downstream markets. Additionally, the region has well-developed infrastructure and is home to major trading ports, attracting manufacturers to the region. The region also has a unique culture with historical ties and strong patriotism. This creates high demand for state, historical and cultural flags further attracting flag manufacturers.

The West region is the second-largest region by industry establishment. California is the largest state by establishment within the region. Flag manufacturers locate in California because of its proximity to major ports and trading partners. California's large size, population, and control of the Pacific coast make it a popular location for manufacturers. Its shared border with Mexico also

The Southwest is the third-largest region by industry establishment. Texas is the largest state in the region by industry establishment, supported by a large population and business-friendly policies. Additionally, the region has access to natural resources used for flag manufacturing and is home to a strong transportation infrastructure.

regulations_points.regulation_description: These laws protect the intellectual property rights of designs and logos on flags. Flag manufacturers need to ensure they have the right to produce flags with specific designs or logos to avoid infringing on existing patents or trademarks, causing costly legal disputes.

Flag manufacturers that import raw materials or finished products are subject to US customs duties. These customs duties can significantly impact the cost of imported goods, affecting profitability and competitive pricing strategies for companies in the industry.

The flag manufacturing industry is required to comply with strict environmental laws regarding waste disposal and chemical emissions. Non-compliance can result in significant fines and penalties, affecting a company's financial performance and reputation.

Compliance with US labor and wage laws is crucial for flag manufacturers. These regulations cover aspects such as occupational health and safety, working hours, overtime pay, and employee conditions. Violations can lead to fines and legal ramifications.

regulations_points.regulation_title: FLAG MANUFACTURERS ASSOCIATION OF AMERICA (FMAA) CERTIFICATION
regulations_points.regulation_description: To be certified by the FMAA, a flag manufacturer must produce flags using 100% US-made materials and processes. This certification can be a selling point for companies, as some consumers prefer products made entirely in the US. However, this also imposes additional constraints, as companies must ensure their entire supply chain meets these regulations.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Flag manufacturers must comply with various regulations, including environmental laws, labor and wage standards, and intellectual property rights.

There are significant start-up costs required to establish a manufacturing facility, including the acquisition of equipment and raw materials, which can create a financial barrier for new entrants to the flag manufacturing industry.

The Flag Manufacturing industry is characterized by high market share concentration, with major players being well-known with a loyal customer base. This makes it challenging for new entrants to differentiate themselves and gain a significant market share.

Flag manufacturing is labor-intensive and requires a skilled workforce for production and quality control. The potential difficulty in securing and maintaining such a workforce presents another barrier to entry for new industry players.

basis_points.basis_description: Operators in the Flag Manufacturing industry compete on quality, price and brand reputation. Since flags are often purchased to last for a long period of time, quality is an important factor for a consumer's purchasing decision.

Operators also compete with external operators. Some flags are used as decorations, and therefore, may compete with other decoration manufacturing industries. For example, banners are a close substitute to flags and are not included in the industry. Imports are another significant form of external competition for the industry.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The Flag Manufacturing industry has a high market share concentration, with the largest company, Annin Flagmakers, accounting for over half of industry revenue.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Economies of Scale Benefit Large Operators
concentration_points.concentration_description: Larger flag manufacturers in the US can produce flags at a lower cost per unit because of economies of scale. These manufacturers can buy raw materials in bulk, have larger production facilities and can spread their fixed costs over a greater number of units.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Industry profit, measured as earnings before interest and taxes, is expected to account for 5.0% of industry revenue in 2023. Profit has fallen in line with declining demand during the period, as competition from imports, which has been exacerbated by rising e-commerce sales, has squeezed industry operators' profit margin. Moreover, the temporary closure of industry establishments during the coronavirus and increased operating costs related to mitigating the spread of the virus have also hampered profit.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: High Labor Intensity Keeps Wages High
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages are expected to account for 22.6% of industry revenue in 2023. This decline in revenue has outpaced wage declines during the period, despite operators seeking to cut wages to decelerate profit decline. Although industry operators have increasingly invested in automation over the past five years, the industry remains highly labor-intensive.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases Are The Largest Cost For Operators
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchase costs are estimated to account for 45.2% of industry revenue in 2023. Industry operators buy cotton, nylon, polyester and other materials used in the production of flags. These costs constitute the largest portion of industry revenue, as the manufacture of industry products requires various inputs that are not produced in-house.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The Flag Manufacturing industry has a low level of capital intensity, with operators spending $0.07 on capital expenditure for every $1.00 invested in labor in 2023. IBISWorld estimates that depreciation accounts for 1.5% of revenue in 2023, which indicates that the industry is labor-intensive.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Workers employed by this industry perform detail-oriented functions, like cutting and sewing fabric.
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Most of these manufacturing activities take place abroad, especially in Asia, where labor costs are lower and environmental regulations are more relaxed. Domestic companies have shifted their focus to higher value-added and labor-intensive activities, such as research and development, design, marketing and manufacturing of premium goods. Additionally, US companies have limited their capital investments domestically as they shift most of their production abroad. Consequently, the capital intensity level has remained relatively steady over the past five years. Continued offshoring and outsourcing of repetitive manufacturing tasks to low labor-cost countries over the next five years is expected to keep capital intensity low.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: The industry is adding new patent technologies at a rate in line with the average across all industries, which suggests a stable addition of technology.
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: However, the concentration of technologies is high. This creates the potential for innovation outside the focus of industry leaders to gain traction.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated, which implies that the market has a focus on key customer segments.
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: This presents an opportunity for strategic entrance into lower-end markets or unserved markets for innovations to take on a disruptive trajectory.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Current events and seasonality affect volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Revenue volatility for the Flag Manufacturing industry is moderate. Industry revenue is tied to political campaign cycles as flag sales tend to rise during the run-up to elections. Moreover, sales tend to rise during summer months as parades and national holidays which invoke increased patriotism happen in the summer. Additionally, current events like international sports competitions can increase demand for the industry, further increasing volatility.
Flag manufacturers rely on raw materials like cotton or nylon for the manufacturing process. Changes in the price of required materials can cause volatility to increase in the industry.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The Flag Manufacturing industry displays low technological development because of its labor intensity and limited development of fully automated machinery. Due to specifications regarding each type of flag, some flags require more manual labor to ensure they meet customer expectations. However, the industry does use current technology and operators endure research and development costs in an attempt to find the best quality materials. Industry operators manufacture flags using advanced stand-up sewing production techniques, digital printing technologies and technology to advance their dye formulas. The type of technology used may depend on the type of flag being produced. For example, the production of the American flag is generally more labor-intensive than a standard flag.

FAQs.question: How have imports from low-wage countries like China and Mexico impacted your operations?
FAQs.answer: Low-priced imports present a significant competitive threat to companies within the industry. Over the past five years imports are anticipated to rise, driven primarily by rising imports from China. Consequently, many operators have shifted to provide higher quality, expensive and value-added products to differentiate from imported competition.

FAQs.question: Have exports offered an opportunity for your company?
FAQs.answer: Over the past five years, industry exports are expected to have been pressured. This has been driven by tepid global demand for industry products amid the coronavirus. Nonetheless, exports remain an important market for the industry.

FAQs.question: Have you looked into setting up manufacturing facilities in lower-wage regions of the country?
FAQs.answer: By offshoring of production facilities to developing countries with lower labor costs, companies are able to completely price their products without having to sacrifice their margins. This trend has caused globalization to trade to become key influencers of industry performance.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Cotton is an input in many flag manufacturing processes, so fluctuations in the price of cotton can have a significant affect on companies.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing in technology to establish a competitive edge?
FAQs.answer: Due to high price-based competition, companies are shifting production toward high-value flags. The detailed features that add value to these more expensive products are often hand-made, and remain more labor-intensive than technology intensive.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Workers employed by this industry perform detail-oriented functions, such as cutting and sewing fabric. As a result, it is difficult for companies to automate production. However, companies have increasingly invested in automation through the use of digital printers, dyeing jigs and tenter frames.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: During the coronavirus, industry operators incurred additional expenses related to outfitting facilities with coronavirus mitigation methods such as the use of personal protective equipment and plastic shields between workers in factories.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: The Flag Manufacturers Association of America brings flag manufacturers and suppliers together in collaboration and conversation. The FMAA also is dedicated to educating the public on the quality of flags made in the USA.

FAQs.question: How often does your company purchase new equipment?
FAQs.answer: Expenditure on wages in this industry accounts for a much larger portion of revenue than expenditure on capital. IBISWorld estimates that a typical firm within this industry spends a mere $0.07 on capital equipment for each dollar spent on labor in 2023. However, operators are likely to increasingly purchase new equipment to automate the flag production process during the outlook period.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare with your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Profit varies among industry operators. Larger operators tend to maintain higher profit margins due to economies of scale and increased investment in technology which lowers labor intensity.

FAQs.question: Are you able to leverage economies of scale? Does your company rely on economies of scale to maintain a healthy profit margin? What is your budget for expanding operations?
FAQs.answer: Companies that can reduce the marginal cost of the flags they produce have a competitive advantage. Investing in machinery which increases automation is usually the way operators do this.

FAQs.question: Do you have a strong reputation among customers? Are you known for your reliability and performance?
FAQs.answer: Having a good reputation among customers is key to raising brand loyalty and securing repeat customers. Moreover, industry operators products are often more expensive than foreign counterparts and consequently,

FAQs.question: Are you located near major suppliers? Do you have good relations with product suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Being within a short distance of raw material suppliers (e.g. cotton suppliers or polyester fiber suppliers) can alleviate potential logistical problems and cut down on transportation costs.

FAQs.question: Do you experience strong competition from imports?
FAQs.answer: The Flag Manufacturing industry experiences strong competition from imports. Import penetration into the manufacturing sector has increased over the past five years.

FAQs.question: Have you offshored production to save money?
How is your company affected by nonresidential contractors? Do you have any major contracts in place?
FAQs.answer: New construction is beneficial to the industry as new buildings often get new flags. The value of private nonresidential construction is expected to increase in 2023.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor fluctuations in per capita disposable income? How have fluctuations affected your business model in the past?
FAQs.answer: Per capita disposable income determines the amount of money that consumers are willing and able to spend on discretionary items, such as flags. Per capita disposable income has increased during the period and has enabled consumers to purchase industry products, which are often more expensive than foreign-produced flags.
